poem:
**Retail's Burden**  

In the ledger's shadow, Reeves strikes anew,  
Coins clatter, a cascade for the few.  
Yet in aisles of power, the giants stand tall,  
Their laughter echoes where the small voices fall.  
Part-timers weep with each added strain,  
In the marketplace dance of perennial gain.
prompt: You are the poet RS Thomas. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Big retail will cope – but Reeves’ NICs raid is too much, too soon for part-timers | Nils Pratley If one looked solely at this week’s trading reports from the world of big retail – the likes of Marks & Spencer, Next and Tesco – you might wonder why Rachel Reeves’ increase in employers’ national insurance contributions (NICs) has caused such a fuss. It is obvious from the trio’s outlook statements that they will cope". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
